questions.question: A car accelerates uniformly from an initial velocity of $5.0\text{ m/s}$ to a final velocity of $25\text{ m/s}$ over a distance of $100\text{ m}$. Calculate the magnitude of the constant acceleration.
A bicycle traveling at a constant velocity of $12\text{ m/s}$ applies its brakes and comes to a uniform stop in $4.0\text{ s}$. Calculate the distance covered by the bicycle while braking.
A stone is dropped from rest from a bridge and hits the water $3.0\text{ s}$ later. Neglecting air resistance, calculate the height of the bridge above the water. Use $g=9.8\text{ m/s}^2$.

A ball is thrown vertically upward from hand level and returns to the thrower's hand $2.0\text{ s}$ later. Neglecting air resistance, calculate the magnitude of the initial upward velocity. Use $g = 9.8\text{ m/s}^2$.
questions.explanation: Time to top is $1.0\text{ s}$. Using $v = u + at$: $0 = u - 9.8(1.0) \rightarrow u = 9.8\text{ m/s}$.

questions.question: A plane flying horizontally at a constant speed of $180\text{ km/h}$ at an altitude of $200\text{ m}$ drops a care package. Neglecting air resistance, calculate the horizontal distance the package travels from its release point to the point of impact.
questions.explanation: $v_x = 180/3.6 = 50\text{ m/s}$. Fall time: $200 = 4.9t^2 \rightarrow t = 6.39\text{ s}$. Distance: $d = 50 \times 6.39 \approx 320\text{ m}$.

questions.question: A projectile is launched from ground level with an initial speed of $30\text{ m/s}$ at an angle of $30^{\circ}$ above the horizontal. Neglecting air resistance, calculate the total time of flight until the projectile returns to ground level.
Determine the maximum height reached by a projectile launched from ground level with an initial speed of $20\text{ m/s}$ at an angle of $60^{\circ}$ above the horizontal. Neglect air resistance.

A boat heads directly across a river, pointing perpendicular to the banks, at a speed of $3.0\text{ m/s}$ relative to the water. The river current flows parallel to the banks at $4.0\text{ m/s}$. Calculate the magnitude of the boat's resultant velocity relative to an observer on the bank.

Car A travels East at a constant speed of $100\text{ km/h}$ and Car B travels West at a constant speed of $100\text{ km/h}$. Calculate the velocity of Car A as measured by an observer in Car B (i.e., the velocity of Car A relative to Car B).
questions.explanation: Relative velocity: $v_{A/B} = v_A - v_B = 100 - (-100) = 200\text{ km/h East}$.

questions.question: A box of mass $10\text{ kg}$ is pushed across a horizontal surface with a constant applied force of $50\text{ N}$. If the box accelerates at $2.0\text{ m/s}^2$, calculate the coefficient of kinetic friction between the box and the surface.

A hockey puck of mass $1.0\text{ kg}$ slides across ice with an initial speed of $5.0\text{ m/s}$. If the coefficient of kinetic friction between the puck and the ice is $\mu_k = 0.20$, calculate the time it takes for the puck to slide to a stop.
Calculate the magnitude of the impulse required to bring a car of mass $1000\text{ kg}$ traveling at a speed of $20\text{ m/s}$ to a complete stop.
questions.explanation: Impulse $J = \Delta p = m\Delta v = 1000(0 - 20) = -20000\text{ N·s}$. Magnitude: $2.0 \times 10^4\text{ N·s}$.

questions.question: A block of mass $10\text{ kg}$ rests on a frictionless incline that makes an angle of $30^{\circ}$ with the horizontal. Calculate the magnitude of the component of the block's weight that acts parallel to the surface of the incline.

A block slides down a frictionless incline that makes an angle of $30^{\circ}$ with the horizontal. Starting from rest, calculate the time it takes for the block to travel a distance of $10\text{ m}$ along the incline.

In an Atwood machine, two masses, $M_1 = 5.0\text{ kg}$ and $M_2 = 10\text{ kg}$, are connected by a light string passing over a frictionless, massless pulley. Calculate the acceleration of the system when it is released from rest.

A $2.0\text{ kg}$ block on a horizontal table with coefficient of kinetic friction $\mu_k = 0.10$ is connected by a light string over a frictionless pulley to a $1.0\text{ kg}$ hanging mass. Calculate the tension in the string when the system is released.
A mass of $1.0\text{ kg}$ is suspended by two identical light strings, each making an angle of $45^{\circ}$ with the vertical. Calculate the tension in each string.
A person with a mass of $70\text{ kg}$ stands on a scale inside an elevator that is accelerating upward at $2.0\text{ m/s}^2$. What is the reading on the scale (the apparent weight of the person)?
A wheel of radius $0.50\text{ m}$ rotates at $600\text{ rpm}$ (revolutions per minute). Assuming no slipping, calculate the linear speed of a point on the rim in $\text{m/s}$.
An object moving in uniform circular motion has a centripetal acceleration of $20\text{ m/s}^2$. If the radius of the circular path is $5.0\text{ m}$, calculate the frequency of rotation.

A mass of $1.0\text{ kg}$ is attached to a string and whirled in a vertical circle of radius $1.0\text{ m}$. If the speed of the mass at the bottom of the circle is $5.0\text{ m/s}$, calculate the tension in the string at that instant.
Calculate the maximum constant speed at which a car can travel over the crest of a circular hill with a radius of curvature of $50\text{ m}$ without losing contact with the road.
A mass of $0.10\text{ kg}$ is whirled in a horizontal circle of radius $0.50\text{ m}$. If the tension in the string is $2.0\text{ N}$, calculate the speed of the mass.
A curve on a highway has a radius of $100\text{ m}$ and is designed for a safe speed of $20\text{ m/s}$ with no friction required. Calculate the banking angle of the curve.

Calculate the distance between the centers of two objects, each of mass $500\text{ kg}$, if the magnitude of the gravitational force of attraction between them is $1.0 \times 10^{-7}\text{ N}$. Use $G = 6.67 \times 10^{-11}\text{ N·m}^2/\text{kg}^2$.

A satellite orbits a planet in a circular orbit at a distance $R$ from the planet's center. If the satellite were moved to a new circular orbit at a distance $9R$ from the planet's center, by what factor would its orbital speed change?

A block of mass $10\text{ kg}$ is pulled at a constant speed a distance of $10\text{ m}$ up a rough incline. If the constant kinetic friction force acting on the block is $10\text{ N}$, calculate the work done by the friction force on the block.

A ball of mass $0.10\text{ kg}$ is moving horizontally at a speed of $30\text{ m/s}$ when it is caught and stopped by a fielder. If the fielder's hand moves backward $0.30\text{ m}$ while stopping the ball, calculate the average force exerted by the ball on the hand.
Calculate the net work required to accelerate a car of mass $1000\text{ kg}$ from a speed of $10\text{ m/s}$ to a speed of $20\text{ m/s}$. Assume all work done goes into changing the kinetic energy.

A mass of $1.0\text{ kg}$ is fired vertically upward from a spring gun. The spring has a spring constant $k = 500\text{ N/m}$ and is compressed by $0.10\text{ m}$ before firing. Neglecting air resistance and the mass of the spring, calculate the maximum height reached by the mass above its launch point.

A $5.0\text{ kg}$ block slides from rest down a frictionless ramp from a height of $3.0\text{ m}$. At the bottom of the ramp, it continues along a rough horizontal surface where friction brings it to a stop. If its speed at the very bottom of the ramp is measured to be $4.0\text{ m/s}$, calculate the amount of thermal energy generated due to friction on the horizontal surface.
An electric motor with an efficiency of $60\%$ draws $1000\text{ W}$ of electrical power. At what constant speed can this motor lift a load of mass $40\text{ kg}$ vertically upward?
Calculate the horsepower required to lift a mass of $100\text{ kg}$ vertically upward a distance of $10\text{ m}$ in $5.0\text{ s}$. Use the conversion $1\text{ hp} = 746\text{ W}$.

A block of mass $1.0\text{ kg}$ moves horizontally at $4.0\text{ m/s}$ and collides with a light horizontal spring with spring constant $k = 800\text{ N/m}$. Assuming no friction, calculate the maximum compression of the spring.

If $10\text{ J}$ of work is required to stretch a particular spring by $5\text{ cm}$ from its natural length, how much work (in J) is required to stretch it an additional $5\text{ cm}$ (i.e., from $5\text{ cm}$ to $10\text{ cm}$)?
questions.explanation: $W \propto x^2$. $10\text{ J}$ for $5\text{ cm}$ means $40\text{ J}$ for $10\text{ cm}$. Additional $= 40 - 10 = 30\text{ J}$.

questions.question: A car of mass $1000\text{ kg}$ moving at $10\text{ m/s}$ collides head-on and locks bumpers with a stationary truck of mass $1500\text{ kg}$. Assuming the collision is perfectly inelastic, calculate the final velocity of the combined wreck immediately after the collision.

A ball of mass $2.0\text{ kg}$ moving at $4.0\text{ m/s}$ undergoes an elastic head-on collision with a stationary ball of mass $2.0\text{ kg}$. Calculate the velocity of the second ball immediately after the collision.
questions.explanation: Equal mass elastic collision: velocities exchange. Second ball takes $4.0\text{ m/s}$.

questions.question: An object of mass $1.0\text{ kg}$ initially at rest explodes into two pieces. One piece, of mass $0.4\text{ kg}$, moves away at $10\text{ m/s}$ due East. Calculate the kinetic energy of the other piece, which has a mass of $0.6\text{ kg}$, immediately after the explosion.
A $12\text{ V}$ battery is connected in series with a $100\Omega$ resistor and a $200\Omega$ resistor. Calculate the voltage drop across the $100\Omega$ resistor.
Two resistors connected in series have a total equivalent resistance of $600\Omega$. If the ratio of their individual resistances is $1:2$, find the resistance of the smaller resistor.
Calculate the equivalent resistance of three resistors, each with a resistance of $100\Omega$, connected in parallel.
Four identical resistors are connected in parallel. The equivalent resistance of this combination is $10\Omega$. Calculate the resistance of each individual resistor.

A $20\Omega$ resistor is connected in parallel with another $20\Omega$ resistor. This parallel combination is then connected in series with a $10\Omega$ resistor. Calculate the total equivalent resistance of this circuit.

A $10\text{ V}$ battery is connected to a circuit consisting of a $10\Omega$ resistor in series with a parallel combination of two $20\Omega$ resistors. Calculate the total power dissipated in the circuit.
A wave travels a distance of $20\text{ m}$ in $4.0\text{ s}$. If the wavelength is $0.50\text{ m}$, calculate the frequency of the wave.
A string of length $1.0\text{ m}$ and total mass $2.0\text{ g}$ is under a tension of $50\text{ N}$. Calculate the fundamental frequency of vibration for this string.

A person standing on a stationary platform hears the whistle of a train. The frequency heard as the train approaches is $500\text{ Hz}$, and the frequency heard as it recedes is $400\text{ Hz}$. Assuming the speed of sound is $v_s=340\text{ m/s}$, calculate the speed of the train.

Two speakers are separated by a distance of $3.0\text{ m}$ and emit a $500\text{ Hz}$ tone in phase. The speed of sound is $340\text{ m/s}$. At what distance from the center point along the line joining the two speakers is the first point of constructive interference located?
questions.explanation: $\lambda = 340/500 = 0.68\text{ m}$. Path difference for constructive: $\Delta = \lambda = 0.68\text{ m}$. $2x = 0.68 \rightarrow x = 0.34\text{ m}$ from center.

questions.question: Calculate the length of an open-end organ pipe (open at both ends) that has a third harmonic frequency of $1029\text{ Hz}$. Take the speed of sound as $v_s = 343\text{ m/s}$.
Two sound waves with frequencies of $300\text{ Hz}$ and $305\text{ Hz}$ interfere. Calculate the beat frequency produced.
